articles.headline: With Nuclear Test, North Korea’s Leader Asserts Role of Instigator
articles.snippet: Kim Jong-un is often dismissed as erratic, but this week he increased tensions between the United States and China and put more pressure on South Korea.
articles.abstract: Kim Jong-un is often dismissed as erratic, but this week he increased tensions between the United States and China and put more pressure on South Korea.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The young leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un, has often been dismissed as inexperienced, erratic and even clueless. But with the North’s test of a nuclear bomb this week, he appears to have mastered a strategy that has served his reclusive country well: playing one big power against another.

articles.headline: Mandatory Union Fees Getting Hard Look by Supreme Court
articles.snippet: The justices have already voiced skepticism about making people give money to public unions. They may now be ready to rule that it’s unconstitutional.
articles.abstract: The justices have already voiced skepticism about making people give money to public unions. They may now be ready to rule that it’s unconstitutional.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — Harlan Elrich is a high school teacher in California, and that means he must pay about $970 a year to a labor union. He teaches math, and he said the system did not add up.

articles.headline: El Chapo, Escaped Mexican Drug Lord, Is Recaptured in Gun Battle
articles.snippet: El Chapo was caught in the city of Los Mochis, a seaside area in his home state, Sinaloa.
articles.abstract: El Chapo was caught in the city of Los Mochis, a seaside area in his home state, Sinaloa.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — He became a byword for government incompetence, a figure who seemed invincible after he burrowed his way out of the country’s most secure prison.

articles.headline: In Insider Trading Settlement, Steven Cohen Will Be Free to Manage Outside Money in 2 Years
articles.snippet: The billionaire investor, who faced the prospect of a lifetime ban, will be barred until 2018, under a settlement with the S.E.C.
articles.abstract: The billionaire investor, who faced the prospect of a lifetime ban, will be barred until 2018, under a settlement with the S.E.C.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire investor, is walking away largely unscathed from nearly a decade of investigations by federal prosecutors and securities regulators into accusations of insider trading at his former hedge fund.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Marco Rubio’s Iowa Supporters Beg Him: Come Visit. Often.
articles.snippet: As the Feb. 1 caucuses approach, people in the state’s smaller towns want to see him spend more time among them making personal connections.
articles.abstract: As the Feb. 1 caucuses approach, people in the state’s smaller towns want to see him spend more time among them making personal connections.
articles.lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — Scott Schneidermann, one of Senator Marco Rubio’s supporters from northwest Iowa, saw all the hallmarks of a campaign on the upswing: a rapt audience of 200, nowhere left to sit, a crush of out-of-town reporters.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: Doctors Unionize to Resist the Medical Machine
articles.snippet: An Oregon medical center’s plan to increase efficiency by outsourcing doctors drove a group of its hospitalists to fight back by banding together.
articles.abstract: An Oregon medical center’s plan to increase efficiency by outsourcing doctors drove a group of its hospitalists to fight back by banding together.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early in the morning on Aug. 12, 2015, a 68-year-old man named Barry turned up at PeaceHealth Sacred Heart Medical Center in Springfield, Ore., confused and feverish.

articles.headline: Chasing the Lure of a Royal Past With Greyhound Racing in Punjab
articles.snippet: By racing dogs in an unmarked field, wealthy Sikh landowners — some of them gas station moguls in the United States — are trying to keep alive the ways of the maharajahs.
articles.abstract: By racing dogs in an unmarked field, wealthy Sikh landowners — some of them gas station moguls in the United States — are trying to keep alive the ways of the maharajahs.
articles.lead_paragraph: FARIDKOT, India — A column of 4-by-4s turned off a dusty road in rural Punjab last week, past ox carts and farmworkers holding sickles, and came to a stop in an unmarked field. Servants circled around to the backs of the vehicles and unloaded, ever so carefully, the animals everyone had come to see.

articles.headline: ‘Broken System’ Allows ISIS to Profit From Looted Antiquities
articles.snippet: A police raid in Bulgaria was heralded as a rare success against the trafficking of antiquities, but it also highlighted the barriers officials face.
articles.abstract: A police raid in Bulgaria was heralded as a rare success against the trafficking of antiquities, but it also highlighted the barriers officials face.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHUMEN, Bulgaria — Acting on a tip, the police raided four homes in eastern Bulgaria, looking for contraband that regularly traverses this country on the way to markets in Western Europe and America. In one rusting shed behind an apartment block here, they found a cache of looted antiquities: 19 classical statues and fragments of marble or limestone.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Nicholas Kulish

articles.headline: Challenging Uber, Lyft Bets on a Road Wide Enough for Two
articles.snippet: Effective monopolies are the rule in technology companies. But with a recent billion-dollar investment, Lyft may show that ride-hailing is an exception.
articles.abstract: Effective monopolies are the rule in technology companies. But with a recent billion-dollar investment, Lyft may show that ride-hailing is an exception.
articles.lead_paragraph: The word “monopoly” has a distinctly nefarious ring to it, conjuring up images of thuggish industrialists in smoky rooms, scheming to undermine their rivals.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: For Republicans, Mounting Fears of Lasting Split
articles.snippet: In an election campaign with a different, angry feel, the party’s establishment is facing a people’s coup.
articles.abstract: In an election campaign with a different, angry feel, the party’s establishment is facing a people’s coup.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Republican Party is facing a historic split over its fundamental principles and identity, as its once powerful establishment grapples with an eruption of class tensions, ethnic resentments and mistrust among working-class conservatives who are demanding a presidential nominee who represents their interests.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Mexico Moves to Extradite Drug Kingpin Called El Chapo to the U.S.
articles.snippet: Mexican officials said the process to extradite Joaquín Guzmán Loera could take months, and his lawyers are expected to fight it.
articles.abstract: Mexican officials said the process to extradite Joaquín Guzmán Loera could take months, and his lawyers are expected to fight it.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — After long resisting requests from Washington, the Mexican government is moving toward extraditing Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the Mexican drug lord known as El Chapo, to the United States to face drug and murder charges there, Mexican officials said on Saturday.

articles.headline: China’s Hunger for Commodities Wanes, and Pain Spreads Among Producers
articles.snippet: For years, China gobbled up metals, crops and fuels for its rapidly expanding economy, and producers aggressively broadened operations to satisfy China’s appetite. Now, all has changed.
articles.abstract: For years, China gobbled up metals, crops and fuels for its rapidly expanding economy, and producers aggressively broadened operations to satisfy China’s appetite. Now, all has changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chile is expanding its largest open-pit copper mine below the northern desert to dig up 1.7 billion additional tons of minerals, even as metal prices plummet around the globe.

articles.headline: Sean Penn Met With ‘El Chapo’ for Interview in His Hide-Out
articles.snippet: Before he was captured, Joaquín Guzmán Loera met with the actor in his jungle hide-out for seven hours in October and spoke about his empire, Donald Trump and the movie business for Rolling Stone.
articles.abstract: Before he was captured, Joaquín Guzmán Loera met with the actor in his jungle hide-out for seven hours in October and spoke about his empire, Donald Trump and the movie business for Rolling Stone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the Mexican drug lord known as El Chapo, started out in business not long after turning 6, selling oranges and soft drinks. By 15, he said in an interview conducted in a jungle clearing by the actor and director Sean Penn for Rolling Stone magazine, he had begun to grow marijuana and poppies because there was no other way for his impoverished family to survive.

articles.headline: The Larger, but Quieter Than Bundy, Push to Take Over Federal Land
articles.snippet: A growing Republican-led movement is pushing the federal government to hand the states millions of acres of Western public lands — as well as their rich stores of coal, timber and grazing grass.
articles.abstract: A growing Republican-led movement is pushing the federal government to hand the states millions of acres of Western public lands — as well as their rich stores of coal, timber and grazing grass.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — Ken Ivory, a Republican state representative from Utah, has been roaming the West with an alluring pitch to cattle ranchers, farmers and conservatives upset with how Washington controls the wide-open public spaces out here: This land is your land, he says, and not the federal government’s.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Kirk Johnson

articles.headline: Ted Cruz’s Diligent Courting of Evangelicals Pays Off in Iowa
articles.snippet: Mr. Cruz’s success in consolidating evangelical Christian voters in Iowa reflects how he has methodically pursued the state’s Christian right.
articles.abstract: Mr. Cruz’s success in consolidating evangelical Christian voters in Iowa reflects how he has methodically pursued the state’s Christian right.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — On Sunday, Pastor Bradley Cranston stood at his pulpit in Burlington, Iowa, and, citing Exodus 18:21 (“select out of all the people able men who fear God ... as leaders”), endorsed Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, urging his parishioners to also consider voting for him.

articles.headline: Yahoo’s Brain Drain Shows a Loss of Faith Inside the Company
articles.snippet: Faced with the failure of her efforts to reignite growth at Yahoo, Marissa Mayer is now turning to the opposite strategy: cutting jobs.
articles.abstract: Faced with the failure of her efforts to reignite growth at Yahoo, Marissa Mayer is now turning to the opposite strategy: cutting jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Marissa Mayer, the glamorous, geeky Google executive hired to turn around Yahoo in 2012, used to inspire hope in Yahoo’s work force just by visiting the cafeteria for ice cream and mingling.

articles.headline: Kate del Castillo, Actress Tied to ‘El Chapo,’ Set Up Sean Penn Meeting
articles.snippet: Ms. del Castillo, a Mexican television star, is believed to have brokered the meeting between the drug lord, Joaquín Guzmán Loera, and Mr. Penn last year.
articles.abstract: Ms. del Castillo, a Mexican television star, is believed to have brokered the meeting between the drug lord, Joaquín Guzmán Loera, and Mr. Penn last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Last fall was a busy time for the Mexican television star Kate del Castillo. She became an American citizen, advertised her new tequila and appeared tirelessly to promote her new film “The 33,” a retelling of the story of the trapped Chilean miners in 2010, in which she stars alongside Antonio Banderas as his valiant wife.

articles.headline: Super Bowl 50 Commercials Are Expected to Have a Lighter Tone
articles.snippet: TV ads often reflect the mood of the times, but many criticized those that aired during last year’s game as gloomy. This year, despite turmoil in the news, the spots are likely to be more fun.
articles.abstract: TV ads often reflect the mood of the times, but many criticized those that aired during last year’s game as gloomy. This year, despite turmoil in the news, the spots are likely to be more fun.
articles.lead_paragraph: For this year’s Super Bowl, marketers want to have fun again.

articles.headline: Ultra Embraces Streaming Singles to Keep a Dance Genre Booming
articles.snippet: “Nothing is more cumbersome than a piece of plastic when all you want is the music,” said Patrick Moxey, founder of the electronic dance music label Ultra Music.
articles.abstract: “Nothing is more cumbersome than a piece of plastic when all you want is the music,” said Patrick Moxey, founder of the electronic dance music label Ultra Music.
articles.lead_paragraph: The disco ball was spinning like a glitter moon and a pair of go-go dancers grooved in neon wigs at a Brooklyn nightclub during the recent 20th-anniversary party of Ultra Music, one of the record labels behind the explosive growth of dance music in the United States.

articles.headline: Starving Syrians in Madaya Are Denied Aid Amid Political Jockeying
articles.snippet: As international powers intensify military and diplomatic activities in Syria, residents in besieged areas have gone without access to food and medicine.
articles.abstract: As international powers intensify military and diplomatic activities in Syria, residents in besieged areas have gone without access to food and medicine.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In the hills near the Lebanese border, an hour’s drive from downtown Damascus, much of a Syrian town is starving, according to residents and international humanitarian workers.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard, Hwaida Saad and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Volkswagen Starts Down Difficult Road of Winning Back Americans
articles.snippet: Executives of the German automaker are embarking on what is perhaps the ultimate hard sell after having broken trust with consumers.
articles.abstract: Executives of the German automaker are embarking on what is perhaps the ultimate hard sell after having broken trust with consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Ever since Volkswagen admitted in September to cheating on diesel emissions tests in the United States, its sales and grand plans for growth in the American market have taken a nosedive.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Mary M. Chapman

articles.headline: How Rolling Stone Handled Ramifications of El Chapo Exclusive
articles.snippet: After Rolling Stone magazine accepted Sean Penn’s pitch for an interview with the outlaw Joaquín Guzmán Loera, communications about the project became coded.
articles.abstract: After Rolling Stone magazine accepted Sean Penn’s pitch for an interview with the outlaw Joaquín Guzmán Loera, communications about the project became coded.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several months ago, Jann Wenner, a founder of Rolling Stone magazine, received a call from the actor Sean Penn.

articles.headline: Neglect May Do What ISIS Didn’t: Breach Iraqi Dam
articles.snippet: The United States is urgently warning the Iraqi government to prepare its people for the dam’s failure, fearing up to 500,000 could be killed if repairs don’t come in time.
articles.abstract: The United States is urgently warning the Iraqi government to prepare its people for the dam’s failure, fearing up to 500,000 could be killed if repairs don’t come in time.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 16 months after Iraqi and Kurdish forces reclaimed Mosul Dam from Islamic State fighters, the structure faces a new threat: the danger that it may collapse because of insufficient maintenance, overwhelming major communities downstream with floodwaters.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Case on Public Sector Union Fees Rouses Political Suspicions
articles.snippet: Lawyers who organized the case are part of a center that is financially backed by conservative foundations. A decision in the plaintiff’s favor could free public sector workers from paying fees if they decline to join unions.
articles.abstract: Lawyers who organized the case are part of a center that is financially backed by conservative foundations. A decision in the plaintiff’s favor could free public sector workers from paying fees if they decline to join unions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It has been nearly 18 years since Hillary Clinton used the term “vast right-wing conspiracy” to describe the conservative forces arrayed against her husband’s administration. But the suspicion about right-wing plotting remains as current on the left as, well, Mrs. Clinton.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Deal Unions a Major Setback
articles.snippet: In a California case, the justices are considering whether government workers who choose not to join a union may still be required to pay for collective bargaining.
articles.abstract: In a California case, the justices are considering whether government workers who choose not to join a union may still be required to pay for collective bargaining.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court seemed poised on Monday to deliver a severe blow to organized labor.
